title: Money Basics
overview: Understand what money is, how it stores value, the difference between income and wealth, and why inflation matters.

modules.title: What is Money?
modules.summary: Definitions, functions of money (medium of exchange, unit of account, store of value).

fixed_qna.q: What is the simplest definition of money?
fixed_qna.a: Money is anything widely accepted in exchange for goods and services; it serves as a medium of exchange, a unit of account, and a store of value.

fixed_qna.q: Why is inflation important for first-time earners?
fixed_qna.a: Inflation reduces purchasing power over time — saving without returns can erode value. That's why understanding simple investing or high-yield savings matters.

title: Budgeting & Saving
overview: Practical methods for budgeting (50/30/20), goals, emergency funds, and automatic saving habits.

modules.title: 50/30/20 and Goal-setting
modules.summary: How to split income, set short/medium/long-term goals, and automate savings.

fixed_qna.a: A simple rule: 50% needs, 30% wants, 20% savings/debt repayment. Use it as a starting point and tweak by personal goals.

fixed_qna.q: How big should an emergency fund be?
fixed_qna.a: Aim for 3–6 months of essential expenses. Start with a small target (₹5,000–₹10,000) and grow it steadily.

title: Debt & Credit
overview: Understand good vs bad debt, interest calculation, credit score basics and how to manage loans and credit cards.

modules.title: Interest & Credit Score
modules.summary: How interest compounds, how credit scores are built, and actions that improve scores.

fixed_qna.a: Compound interest is interest on interest — your debt or investment grows faster when interest accumulates on previously earned interest.

fixed_qna.q: How does credit card use affect score?
fixed_qna.a: Timely payments and low utilization help. Maxing out a card or missing payments hurts your credit score.

title: Investing Basics
overview: Basic investing concepts: risk vs reward, diversification, time horizon, and the idea of compounding returns.

modules.title: Risk & Diversification
modules.summary: Risk types, why diversification reduces risk, and simple portfolio examples for beginners.

fixed_qna.a: Diversification spreads risk across assets so a single loss doesn't wipe out your portfolio.
An index fund is a fund that tracks a market index (e.g., NIFTY/S&P 500) offering broad market exposure and low fees.

title: Stocks & ETFs
overview: How stocks represent ownership, ETFs as baskets, basic order types, and reading simple stock charts.

modules.title: Stocks vs ETFs
modules.summary: Pros/cons of single stocks vs ETFs, fees, and volatility considerations.

fixed_qna.q: Is it safer to buy ETFs than one stock?
fixed_qna.a: Generally yes — ETFs provide immediate diversification, which lowers idiosyncratic risk compared to a single stock.
Yes — ETFs have an expense ratio. Choose low-cost ETFs for long-term investing.

title: Mutual Funds & SIPs
overview: Mutual fund basics, systematic investment plans (SIP), expense ratios, and how SIPs work for rupee-cost averaging.

modules.title: SIP & Rupee-cost Averaging
modules.summary: How regular investments reduce timing risk and the advantages of disciplined SIPs.

fixed_qna.a: A Systematic Investment Plan (SIP) lets you invest a fixed amount at regular intervals into a mutual fund.
You buy more units when prices are low and fewer when prices are high — smoothing entry price over time.

title: Emergency Fund & Insurance
overview: Design emergency savings and choose basic insurance (health, term, asset protection).

modules.title: Emergency Fund Strategy
modules.summary: How to build and maintain an emergency fund, when to use it, and insurance basics.

fixed_qna.q: How much should I keep in emergency fund?
fixed_qna.a: Aim for 3-6 months of essential expenses. Start small and build gradually.

fixed_qna.q: What insurance do I need first?
fixed_qna.a: Start with health insurance, then term life insurance. Asset insurance (home, vehicle) comes next based on your assets.

title: Tax Planning
overview: Overview of common tax concepts, tax-saving investments, and retirement accounts to start early.

modules.title: Tax-efficient Investing
modules.summary: Use tax-advantaged schemes and understand capital gains basics.

fixed_qna.a: Profit from selling investments after a defined period; tax rates often differ from short-term gains.
ELSS mutual funds, PPF, NPS, and tax-saving FDs can help reduce your taxable income under Section 80C.

title: Retirement Planning
overview: Start planning for retirement early, understand retirement accounts, and calculate how much you need.

modules.title: Retirement Basics
modules.summary: Why start early, how much to save, and retirement account options (EPF, PPF, NPS).

fixed_qna.q: When should I start saving for retirement?
fixed_qna.a: Start as early as possible — even small amounts in your 20s can grow significantly due to compound interest.

fixed_qna.q: How much do I need for retirement?
fixed_qna.a: A common rule is 25-30x your annual expenses. Use retirement calculators to estimate based on your lifestyle and inflation.

title: Portfolio Building
overview: Build model portfolios, asset allocation, and portfolio optimization basics for beginners.

modules.title: Asset Allocation
modules.summary: How to allocate assets based on age, risk tolerance, and goals. Simple portfolio frameworks.

fixed_qna.q: How should I allocate my investments?
fixed_qna.a: A common rule: 100 minus your age = % in equities. The rest in bonds and fixed income. Adjust based on risk tolerance.
A mix of stocks, bonds, and other assets that matches your risk tolerance and time horizon.

title: Real Estate Basics
overview: Understanding real estate investment, home buying basics, REITs, and property as an asset class.

modules.title: Real Estate Investment
modules.summary: Buying vs renting, REITs as an alternative, and real estate as part of your portfolio.

fixed_qna.a: Depends on your financial situation, location stability, and local market. Buying requires large down payment and ongoing costs.
Real Estate Investment Trusts let you invest in real estate without buying property directly. They're liquid and diversified.

title: Financial Goals
overview: Setting SMART financial goals, prioritizing goals, and creating action plans to achieve them.

modules.title: Goal Setting
modules.summary: How to set specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and time-bound financial goals.

fixed_qna.q: How do I set financial goals?
fixed_qna.a: Use SMART framework: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound. Start with short-term goals and build to long-term.
Emergency fund first, then high-interest debt payoff, followed by retirement savings, then other goals like buying a home.

title: Money Psychology
overview: How biases (loss aversion, anchoring, herd behavior) affect decisions and techniques to avoid common traps.

modules.title: Common Biases
modules.summary: Recognize and mitigate biases when investing and budgeting.

fixed_qna.a: People feel losses more strongly than equivalent gains, causing overly conservative or reactive decisions.
Use rules (regular investing, checklists) and re-check decisions against goals instead of following the crowd.

title: Crypto & Alternatives
overview: Understanding cryptocurrencies, digital assets, risks, and when/if they fit in a portfolio.

modules.title: Crypto Basics
modules.summary: What is cryptocurrency, blockchain basics, risks, and how to approach crypto investing safely.

fixed_qna.a: Crypto is highly speculative and volatile. Only invest what you can afford to lose, and keep it to a small portion (5-10%) of portfolio if at all.
High volatility, regulatory uncertainty, security risks, and potential for total loss. Treat as high-risk speculative investment.

title: Banking Products
overview: Understanding different banking products, savings accounts, FDs, RDs, and choosing the right bank.

modules.title: Bank Accounts & FDs
modules.summary: Types of accounts, fixed deposits, recurring deposits, and how to choose banking products.

fixed_qna.q: What's the difference between savings and current account?
fixed_qna.a: Savings accounts earn interest and have transaction limits. Current accounts are for businesses with higher transaction volumes.
Yes, FDs are considered very safe as they're insured up to ₹5 lakhs per bank by DICGC. Returns are guaranteed but lower than other investments.

title: Market Fundamentals
overview: Understanding how stock markets work, market cycles, bull and bear markets, and reading market indicators.

modules.title: Market Basics
modules.summary: How markets function, supply and demand, market cycles, and basic market terminology.

fixed_qna.a: A period when stock prices are rising generally, typically 20% or more from recent lows. Investor confidence is high.
A period when stock prices are falling generally, typically 20% or more from recent highs. Investor confidence is low.

title: Risk Management
overview: Understanding different types of risk, how to manage risk, and protecting your investments.

modules.title: Types of Risk
modules.summary: Market risk, credit risk, inflation risk, and how to mitigate each through diversification and strategies.

fixed_qna.q: What are the main types of investment risk?
fixed_qna.a: Market risk (prices go down), credit risk (borrower defaults), inflation risk (purchasing power erodes), and liquidity risk (can't sell quickly).
Diversify across asset classes, invest for long-term, avoid putting all money in one investment, and maintain emergency fund.

title: Scams & Safety
overview: Recognizing investment scams, Ponzi schemes, and how to invest safely through regulated channels.

modules.title: Avoiding Scams
modules.summary: Red flags of investment scams, how to verify legitimacy, and safe investing practices.

fixed_qna.q: How do I spot investment scams?
fixed_qna.a: Warning signs: guaranteed high returns, pressure to invest quickly, unregistered entities, too-good-to-be-true promises.

fixed_qna.q: How do I verify if an investment is legitimate?
fixed_qna.a: Check if registered with SEBI, verify credentials, read fine print, never invest based solely on social media ads or unsolicited calls.
